Award.AwardTitle: Next Generation Alliance of Science Educators Toolkit (Next Gen ASET)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will research the development and application of new Next Generation curriculum exemplars for middle school science and K-12 teacher preparation foundational level general science (collectively referred to as Next Gen curriculum materials). The project will address the need to develop middle school science curriculum that aligns with the expectations of NGSS by (1) constructing diagnostic tools to assess the alignment of curricula; (2) using the tool for existing curricula in order to field test it; and (3) systematically investigating the effectiveness of the tool. The project will use these tools to revise and test a series of middle school lessons, implement them in the classroom, and study their results. Research on the efficacy of these diagnostic tools will address specific content and evidence of learning in two domains: student middle school science learning and teacher content learning.

The project will develop curriculum diagnostic tools for middle school science. The process of development will include field testing with teachers and students in 60 classrooms (20 life, 20 physical, and 20 earth science classrooms) in high needs areas. It will employ rigorous standards in developing and applying research-based procedures to produce NGSS curriculum exemplars. The mixed methodology approach will provide in-depth information regarding the alignment of new curriculum materials to the NGSS. The rigorously analyzed and field-tested Next Generation science curriculum exemplars products produced will be broadly disseminated through state and national conferences and networks of programs with which the California State University, East Bay (CSU East Bay) and core partners are in collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The new vision for science education articulated in the Framework for K12 Science Education was catalyzed by criticism of U.S. science standards as “long lists of detailed and disconnected facts” reinforced by curriculum that was “a mile wide and an inch deep” (NRC, 2012, p. 10). Consensus called for fewer core science concepts with an increased emphasis on scientific practices (NRC, 2012).  Changes in science instruction move towards educators shifting from memorization of key science ideas, isolation of content from science practices, and a single-disciplinary focus toward a multidimensional, interdisciplinary instruction that focuses on what the student is doing to make sense of phenomena. The Three-Dimensional Mapping Tool (3D Map) is a visual scaffold designed for use in science teaching methods courses to help preservice teachers unpack the components of NGSS and support planning of phenomena-based 3-dimensional instruction.  The current NSF project (#1418440) entitled “Alliance for Science Teacher Educators (ASET) Toolkit (2014-2019) devised, tested, researched and implemented a series of tools including a 3-Dimensional Planning Map (3D Map) and guidelines for each of the eight Science and Engineering Practices (SEP tools) for grades K-12.  The 3D Map frames the scope of lessons and instructional strategies targeted for the NGSS, while allowing for connections to additional planning strategies typically included in a science teaching methods course such as the 5E learning cycle (Bybee et al., 2006), backward design (Wiggins & McTighe, 2001), and science literacy (Lee, Quinn, & Valdes, 2013). The SEP tools provide guidance for discourse in enacting the practices set by the Next Generation Science Standards.


The project was implemented within a Networked Improvement Community (NIC) that began with one university and two science education faculty member sand grew (by 2018) to 17 faculty at 11 universities training 1100 total preservice teachers (started at 37 preservice teachers in 2014).

 

The NIC was expanded to include participants at ten universities in California, Kentucky, and Utah as well as a couple individuals associated with school districts. The NIC held monthly virtual meetings throughout the Fall and Spring semesters of the 2018 – 2019 school year with attendance varying from eight to twelve individuals including project staff. The goal of the NIC is to support instructors of science methods courses for pre-service teachers. The meetings followed an agenda sent out in advance and primarily focused on discussions of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), discussions of the tools developed by project staff, and discussions of current literature related to the project. Meetings were always well-planned and all attendees actively engaged in interactions with other attendees and project staff. Members of the NIC are also active participants in the project both as research subjects and as researchers collecting data from the students they teach. The NIC has reached a size in which there is a critical mass of participants who are all actively engaged. If the NIC were to grow beyond its current size the virtual meetings might become unmanageable. If the NIC were to double in size, then the community may need to be split in two. During the Fall semester the NIC was split into two groups with separate meetings occurring each month with each group. This was done to accommodate the schedules of participants with the effect of the smaller group sizes reducing the energy level during meetings. Again, the ideal group size seems to be between eight and twelve participants per meeting.

The NIC has been a way to ensure that the tools developed by the project staff are being actively used to train pre-service science teachers. The NIC is the vehicle through which this project is having an impact on a large number of new science teachers. The tools are providing a framework for both instructors and pre-service teachers to better understand the NGSS and to learn to develop modules and individual lessons that incorporate all three dimensions of the standards. The NIC appears to be providing an effective environment in which this happens. Growth of the NIC could provide a vehicle for rapidly scaling the impact of this work. The members of the NIC are ambassadors for this work and should be encouraged to actively promote use of the ASET tools to other instructors of science methods courses.

An annual meeting of NIC members is held at Cal State East Bay in June of each year to provide members a chance to meet face-to-face and discuss their use of the ASET tools, share three-dimensional science lessons they have developed, and collaborate on project dissemination. This year, the meeting took place June 14 – 15 with thirteen of the fourteen NIC members attending. This level of attendance shows the commitment of NIC members to this project. Commitment to this NIC has continued with the fortunate funding in the next project from the National Science Foundation.
